My neighbors are generally friendly people who will smile and say hello when I walk down the street. Crime rates, while slightly higher than other parts of town, are still generally low. There have been a few violent crimes in the past ten years within a few blocks of my home, including a few shootings and at least one homicide. Our next door neighbors lost their son in a shooting outside an area bar last year. Fortunately, our family has not been directly affected by crime other than having an occasional item disappear from our porch if we forget to bring it inside. In general, the town in which I live has been profoundly affected by the “opioid epidemic” that has affected many parts of the United States. Many lives have been lost due to fentanyl overdoses. Fortunately, there are many resources in my town to combat this epidemic, including several addiction rehabilitation centers and Narcan training sessions for families and friends of those affected by addiction. Despite these challenges, this town has many positive attributes. My son’s elementary school has excellent staff, from the principal to the teachers and support staff. Despite having special needs, he has not faced any bullying thus far due to the incredibly positive atmosphere of the school, and he loves it there. We have an active PTO that plans multiple events throughout the year to promote family involvement and educational progress. Because over 20% of our town’s population lives below the poverty level, the elementary school provides free breakfast and lunch to all students, so that no child ever has to go hungry. No child or family is treated as “less than” due to an inability to pay, and costs for school fees, supplies, and field trips are very reasonable. The City Council and staff have made many improvements to the appearance of our town, including repaving roads, landscaping, and refurbishing city parks. Unfortunately, most of these improvements have taken place in the center of town and on the west side, where all of the shopping areas are located and most of the traffic passes through. The east side where I live tends to be neglected, which is a point of contention for those in my neighborhood. Overall, I do enjoy living in this town. People are generally friendly, the schools are great, there are enough shopping options (both small businesses and larger retail stores) to meet my family’s needs, and our home may not be worth much, but it is comfortable and adequate. Our family has lived here for over 16 years, and we cannot imagine living anywhere else.
My neighborhood is full of culture. It's set upon a hill, surrounded by buildings with historical meaning. I live in a 7 story apartment building right across from the old live Theater, and a block down The Hill, is this cool little arcade bar that different types of people flock to on warm summer nights. Often times, especially on the weekends in June and July, you will see a line of people waiting to get in. A few blocks up is the nearest city park. It's pretty big considering the part of town it sits in. Encircling the park is concrete, with tall stairs poured into the wall. During the frigid winter months, homeless people set their tents up in neat little rows along the sidewalk and along the wide steps. It doesn't snow much, but it rains, and the torrential down pour in the mid-winter months often tends to make it difficult to keep warm. Setting their tents up close together, in the center of town rather than out in the jungle, keeps them much warmer. They're also within reasonable walking and transit distance to the only family center for miles, where they can bathe and shower. What I love about my city though, isn't the beauty of the historic nature- the tall proud buildings, the architecture that is spattered through-out the varying levels of the hills that roll down towards the ocean. What I love about my neighborhood is the culture of the people themselves. You see, Hilltop once was the most notorious neighborhood on the West Coast for gang violence. You still hear stories, even three decades later, about the federal government officials and the DEA sweeping through like a broom, trying to clean the streets. The people, they don't forget. Stories are still passed from generation to generation, on through to transplants like me, of those days. The people work hard, even though it's still considered one of the rougher 'hoods' in the entire city, to keep it cleaned up. They still care about what goes on in their city, on their block. They say that if you're white, you shouldn't walk around the Hill after dark. Truly, I believe that this warning is reminiscent of the old days, and it is tinged with the sour taste of social conditioning. Perhaps it is that I am just dark enough to pass for a not entirely "white-girl," or maybe Hilltop recognizes me as one of their own, someone who is just as painfully aware of the reminders that constantly plague our nation. Reminders that racism, cultural conditioning, and assumptions are made out of ignorance and fear, even in a city that is supposed to be a cultural melting pot Utopia. I know one thing: no matter how far I roam, the Hilltop is home. I feel alive walking those streets at night, meeting people who have more quickly and rarely nefariously offered me a jacket than to rob me. It's a place where laundromat owners have stayed open just a few minutes later so I could charge my phone when I had no where to escape from the rain. It's a place where I have sat, believe myself to be invisible, huddled against concrete store fronts on the most grey dreary of nights, only to have someone stop and look me in the eye, hand me a $5, and tell me I'm beautiful and valuable.
I live in Rural America, specifically small town Michigan. Where you go from farmland to small tourist cities. There is no big city malls, no Wal-mart, Target, or even an Applebee’s. Anywhere you need to go, you have to drive to get to. Despite that I live in one of the most beautiful places in the world surrounded by water. My “city” is surrounded by water. Beautiful Lake Michigan to one side, and Lake Charlevoix on the other. Everywhere you go you can find a beach to dip your toes in. My neighborhood, reflects the idea of small town. Houses are not stacked upon one another. They aren’t cookie cutter houses that are built the same. They are older homes, some of them being updated and remodeled some of them being older. Most homes have basements. Full Basements that you can see from the road. Many houses in the neighborhood have older aluminum siding. We have houses every color you can imagine in the blocks that surround my house. Most of the houses have yards. Yards with trampolines, and playsets. Some people have gardens, and fences for their animals. The houses resemble Middle America. Hard working people who work to make a living and are either raising families or have raised families. On any given day you will see kids running up and down the streets. You will also see people walking dogs, biking and rollerblading. Neighbors know neighbors and you can recognize who fits in and who doesn’t belong. You will see someone grilling outside and wave, or even someone that is walking their dog from a few blocks down and smile pleasantly. The lawns are kept in decent condition. Nobody has leaves piled up from fall time. Green grass is kept mowed and under control. If people have plants and bushes in their yards they are kept trimmed down. It isn’t a beautiful neighborhood that you drive into and think wow look at the nice homes, but one you drive into and think you can tell this would be a good place to raise a family. It’s quiet, peaceful and, and safe. While only average looking, it is exceptional for the fact that it represents what people want in the world, which is a safe place to land at the end of the day. Within walking distance there is the county sheriff’s department and jail. The Health department is just next to that. The city recycling center sits just down the road, and neighbors and residents from around the city utilize the services they provide. We have baseball and softball fields nearby where you can hear the announcers keeping score and calling the names of players. Our small town airport is next to that. You can be playing outside, or even inside and hear the rumbles of small engine planes taking off and landing. You can walk to get ice cream from the local ice cream place, and if you are really into it you can make it downtown from our neighborhood of homes. My kids can ride their bikes to the park which is only 8 blocks or so away. It is a really great place to live.
transformed_texts: Living in a large city like mine has exposed me to an incredible array of cultures and lifestyles. Residential areas seem to be scattered randomly alongside commercial districts, where a wide range of businesses thrive. You'll find everything from sleek office buildings to quirky stores, restaurants, and entertainment venues. The options for dining and shopping are endless, with both well-known brands and unique boutiques popping up in malls and along streets that are often just a short walk from quiet neighborhoods.  My area also boasts a few nearby parks, which are often frequented by families with young children. The diversity of people in my neighborhood is just as striking. In a single location, you'll find a vibrant LGBTQ+ community, an Orthodox Jewish community, and a collection of refugees and immigrants from the former Soviet Union. Just a little further afield, the city is home to numerous other communities of various ethnicities and nationalities, each with their own distinct character. You can explore Korea town, China town, Little Armenia, and many more, all within a short drive. However, the city's size and notorious traffic can make even short trips feel like epic journeys. Rush hour can turn a 10-mile drive into a two-hour ordeal. It's a shame, really, given that hardly anyone in this city walks anywhere. While attractions may be just around the corner, the sheer size of the city means people prefer to drive – and the result is some of the world's worst traffic. Construction is rampant, with new apartment buildings sprouting up left and right, but this has also sparked concerns about overcrowding and further congestion. Not everyone wants to live in a high-rise apartment building, though – my area offers a diverse range of housing options, from single-family homes to duplexes and smaller apartment buildings. Age-wise, the neighborhood is just as diverse, with many residents of different ages. To be honest, I don't really know most of my neighbors these days, but I do have fond memories of playing with my childhood friends in the neighborhood, when it was a closer-knit community.

My neighborhood is a place where time stands still, frozen in the memories of a bygone era. The single-family homes that line the streets tell the story of a dream that once was, a dream of suburban bliss that seemed to capture the essence of American life. However, that dream is slowly fading, and the once-thriving neighborhood is now a reminder of what's been left behind. The houses, though diverse in appearance, share a common thread - a longing for a time when the world was a simpler place. The people who call this neighborhood home are a testament to that nostalgia, clinging to the hope that the dream is still alive, even if it's no longer as vibrant as it once was. The upkeep of the yards may not be what it used to be, but the cars parked in every driveway and the laughter of children playing in the streets are a testament to the resilience of the community. The public school, a 90-year-old institution, stands as a beacon of hope for the future, evoking memories of a bygone era in the hearts of the older residents. The churches, though few and far between, hold a special place in the hearts of the community, while the basketball courts are always bustling with life. Amidst the changing times, the neighborhood remains a constant, a place where tradition and nostalgia blend with the present. The local supermarket, "Super A," is a staple, owned by a family who has been a part of the community for generations, standing out as a rare example of diversity in a predominantly African American neighborhood. The streets are wide, and the kids play football, their laughter and shouts filling the air as they stop only to let cars pass by. The residents, many of whom have lived here for generations, can tell stories of a past where everyone knew everyone, a time when life was simpler and the world was a smaller place. The neighborhood has seen its fair share of changes, from the karate school that once inspired a generation to the pharmacy that now caters to a different kind of need. Even the small movie theater, playing classic films at discounted prices, remains a beloved institution, cherished by the older residents who value a night out without the distractions of modern life. The expressway that passes through the neighboring town, a constant reminder of the outside world, has been a topic of debate, with the youth wanting to bring it to our town and the elders fighting to preserve the neighborhood's character. Now, the town is deciding on a new high school mascot, and I think a cyborg with a country accent and a log cabin would be the perfect representation of our town's unique blend of tradition and innovation.

At first glance, this place may seem unassuming - a residential area nestled behind a row of stores, hardly the kind of place one would expect to find a thriving community.  But venture beyond the old, abandoned Whole Foods and behind the hotels that sit idle most of the year, only occasionally bursting with activity during summer family reunions, and you'll stumble upon a vibrant neighborhood.  This hidden area is home to several apartment complexes, each one a testament to the idea that appearances can be deceiving.  While some of these complexes have made headlines for less-than-desirable reasons, they're not the focus here.  It's the others, the ones that fly under the radar, that are worth exploring.  Located beside these complexes is a community college's satellite campus, a quiet haven where students filter in, bleary-eyed, at 7 am to start their day.  The iron gates creak open to admit them one by one, while drivers behind them shake their fists in frustration.  The road that cuts through this area intersects with another residential street, lined with a park where children play, a rehabilitation center with a cheerful atmosphere, and a strip mall that's home to a sushi restaurant, a swimming supply store, and a nail salon.  You can fill your pool while getting a manicure and enjoying a meal of hibachi chicken - the epitome of convenience.  A frozen yogurt shop and a skate park round out the scene, where teens spend their days doing tricks and sipping on cold, sweet treats.  This neighborhood is a snapshot of small-town America, a slice of history in a region where time stands still.

As we drove through the seemingly endless cornfields that stretched out before us, she looked at me with a mix of confusion and wonder. "Is this it?" she asked, her voice barely above a whisper. I knew she was struggling to comprehend the vast openness of the landscape, a stark contrast to her childhood home where the grocery store was just a stone's throw away. I shared with her what it was like growing up in rural Ohio, surrounded by the endless fields that seemed to swallow the horizon. In that moment, she finally grasped who I was and where I came from. The serenity of the cornfields gave way to a two-lane country road, which wound its way past a tranquil quarry filled with water. Just beyond it lay the quaint development where I resided, a collection of brick and stucco homes with expansive yards that each boasted at least half an acre of land, lovingly tended to by their owners. Springtime brought a kaleidoscope of colors to the landscape, with annually planted flowers and the ever-changing hues of the midwestern trees. The driveways were lined with sleek luxury cars, polished to a shine after a refreshing wash, their gleam a testament to the pride of their owners. As we approached my home, I was greeted by the familiar sight of my neighbor, a kind-hearted Korean man who spent his days tending to his lawn with a warm smile. His gentle demeanor and the soothing hum of his John Deere Zero Turn mower were a comforting presence in our little community. He's a man with a rich history, a doctor by trade, and a treasure trove of stories to share. As we drew closer to my home, the sounds of geese and a playful Terrier filled the air, while the distant "moo" of nearby farms added to the symphony of sounds. A small stream ran through the backyard, its gentle gurgle accompanied by the chirping of bullfrogs and the occasional rustle of leaves. Across a charming handmade wooden bridge lay a hidden oasis, teeming with wildflowers, herbs, and towering trees, a place where I spent countless hours as a child, building forts, chasing after animals, and forging friendships with my neighbors. The winters in our small town were harsh, but there was something beautiful about it, too. The once-thriving landscape would transform into a winter wonderland, with snow-covered trees standing like skeletal sentinels, their branches etched against the pale sky. The occasional snowfall would bring a magical touch, transforming our backyard into a playground of snow angels, snowmen, and fortresses built from branches and imagination. It was a time of unbridled joy, when the world seemed to slow down and all that mattered was the freedom to play and dream.

The essence of Portland, Oregon, lies in its unique definition of "weird". A phrase plastered on a building that serves multiple purposes - a pizza joint, bar, music venue, and even a bit of a grey area in terms of the law - reads "Keep Portland Weird". For some, this is a nostalgic call to remember the Portland of the 90's and early 2000's, a time when the city was lesser-known and more affordable, giving rise to innovative and one-of-a-kind subcultures. For others, it's an invitation to join a community where being called "weird" is actually a compliment. Despite an influx of affluent Californians and the construction of new condominiums to cater to them, Portland remains an anomaly. 

Weird doesn't imply a complete rejection of the norm; it simply means embracing the unconventional. It doesn't mean we're immune to modern conveniences and the issues that come with them - like importing most of our goods from China, just like the rest of the country. Being weird encompasses countless forms of nonconformity, but Portland is also full of its fair share of normalcy - yoga enthusiasts, hipsters, and business professionals. Perhaps the key to being Portland weird is embracing a more carefree attitude towards life. In my neighborhood, as in many others, colorful houses, lush gardens, and free boxes line the streets, often filled with treasures just waiting to be discovered. The magical potential of stumbling upon a hidden gem in a Southeast Portland neighborhood is what makes Portland so endearing to me. However, I'm just one of the many varieties of weird that call this city home. Some of my neighbors would never dream of rummaging through a free box on the sidewalk, opting instead for activities like goat yoga or Timbers matches. Portland is a melting pot of unique interests and passions, where people pursue their dreams or spend hours daydreaming over a drink at the local bar. Yes, Portland grapples with its share of problems - a drug epidemic that often stems from underlying mental health issues, the gloomy weather, and a homelessness crisis that's proving difficult to tackle. Like many cities, we struggle to find a balance between compassion and frustration. In this, we're not as weird as you might expect.

The mountains stand steadfast, bearing witness to the passage of time, unchanged by the ebbs and flows of life. They remain constant, unwavering in their presence, as I navigate the turmoil of everyday life. Their unflinching resolve is a balm to my frazzled soul, reminding me to breathe, to persevere, one day at a time. It's a memory that dates back to my undergraduate days, when the mountains north of campus first captured my heart. While the university's own beauty, in its buildings and ponds and trees, holds a piece of my affection, it's the mountains that reign supreme. The town itself is a tapestry of contrasting scenes - vibrant cafés where late-night cram sessions fueled my caffeine addiction, quaint downtown areas with their faded brick facades, and the hum of activity that rivals the nearby city's. Yet, this urban bustle is tempered by the peaceful atmosphere of the library, beckoning me to escape. It's a dichotomy that draws me in, inviting me to explore and create memories to treasure. Whether it's strolling past the rusted swings in the park with friends after a long night of studying or rushing through the downtown streets to catch a movie, each experience is etched in my memory, tied to a particular location. The ponds, too, have been a sanctuary - a place to reflect, to cry, to grapple with existential questions that have haunted me. As I watch the turtles, ducks, and insects living their lives with purpose, I'm reminded of my own search for meaning. But as I walk north, past the park and the houses that epitomize suburban tranquility, I'm drawn to the majesty of the mountains. The sun casts its golden light upon their peaks, and I'm struck by their unwavering presence. They speak to me without words, stirring within me a sense of resilience.

Visiting Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, won't be a challenge at all, thanks to its excellent public transportation system. As one of the most popular forms of transportation in New York City, getting around is a breeze. This urban neighborhood offers a quintessential New York experience, with a unique blend of cultures and lifestyles. One of the defining features of Bensonhurst is its significant Asian influence, which has grown over the past two decades. As a result, you'll find Asian-owned stores on nearly every block, showcasing a diverse range of businesses, from supermarkets to laundromats. These local favorites are particularly well-loved for their high-quality food, affordable prices, and convenience. Just a short walk from my location, I'm surrounded by four Asian supermarkets within a two-minute radius of each other, making grocery shopping a hassle-free experience.

While Bensonhurst is not exclusively Asian, it's a melting pot of cultures, with immigrants and their families making it their home. The neighborhood is also home to a range of successful Asian-owned businesses, which contribute to its vibrant atmosphere. In addition to these attractions, a recently renovated park offers an array of amenities, including basketball courts, soccer fields, handball courts, playgrounds, and a water fountain for kids to enjoy during the summer months. As with many parks in New York City, Bensonhurst's park is a hub of diversity, where people from different backgrounds come together to play and socialize.

In contrast to the tall corporate buildings you'd find in other parts of the city, Bensonhurst is characterized by co-op living, condominium apartments, and two-family houses. While the residents are generally friendly, they can be quite loud, with cars blaring music and screeching to a halt, waking you up early in the morning. If you plan to visit at night, be aware that while the neighborhood is generally safe, you may encounter unpredictable individuals, including potential bullies and thieves. In my personal experience, I've faced physical bullying in the past, although that was many years ago. More recently, there have been incidents of package theft in the area, which is a common issue in many neighborhoods. Lastly, it's worth noting that some residents seem to neglect to clean up after their dogs, leaving a trail of dog waste behind. My pet peeve is the abundance of dog waste on the sidewalks, so do keep your shoes clean and be mindful of your surroundings.

Where I live, there's a scarcity of sidewalks, and the streets are a slope, with my house perched at the crest of the steepest hill in the neighborhood, which joggers affectionately call the "workout hill." As there are no sidewalks on my street, pedestrians navigate the road, which is pockmarked with potholes and can be hazardous to drive on. The telephone and electric wires crisscrossing the area have a tattered appearance, with frequent power outages causing repairs, leaving the lines to look patchwork. The area is prone to heavy rainfall and storms, which often bring down branches and debris onto the power lines.

Tall evergreen trees dominate the landscape, but the residents have a peculiar affinity for cutting them down, viewing them as obstructions to the ocean view. As a result, many houses are built high up on the hill, with expansive glass-fronted second stories to take in the view of the bay. During sunset, the water appears to be lit from below, casting an orange glow over the sky. However, the sky is often shrouded in a haze, and most days are overcast and damp, with moss thriving on every available surface – roofs, cars, and railings alike. I recall leaving my car parked in the driveway for an extended period, only to return to find it covered in a thick layer of moss that took hours to scrub off.

The neighborhood is notable for its mature residents, many of whom are retired, while children are scarce, despite the nearby school. Dogs have become a ubiquitous presence, with many residents letting them roam freely in their yards or chasing each other down the street. On occasion, these dogs can be a nuisance, sneaking into homes through open doors or windows. Rabbits are also a common sight, and while they can be a nuisance for gardeners who must deal with their digging and burrowing, my cats have taken it upon themselves to hunt them out of our neighborhood. The area is also home to a variety of birds, including sparrows, hummingbirds, and occasional hawks or eagles, which are often chased away by the resident crows. Visitors to the area can hike down to the waterfront, where a few restaurants serve fresh seafood, although the beach itself is not particularly large. The bay is narrow, and on most days, the opposite shoreline can be seen through the mist.

I reside in a small southern town in Tennessee, in a typical suburban neighborhood that's situated on a connecting street between two state highways. While this does bring in a moderate amount of traffic, the rest of the area remains relatively quiet. The neighborhood is quite stable, with not many residents moving in or out, allowing me to become familiar with the people who live here. Everyone seems to be preoccupied with yard work and daily routines. During the winter, we enjoy sledding down a nearby hill on our side street, and our house, located at the front corner of the street, provides a perfect view of the comings and goings of the neighbors. Whenever a stranger's car passes by, we take note of it. Some neighbors take walks for exercise or to walk their dogs, while kids spend their time on their bikes and engaging in other typical neighborhood activities. As we work from home, we're often visible to the neighbors, along with my wife and our two daughters, aged eleven and fourteen. This has created a sense of familiarity among us and the community. On sunny days, we enjoy spending time outdoors, even in the rain. Occasionally, we fire up the barbecue on our back deck, filling the air with the savory smell of sizzling meat. The sound of lawn mowers is a regular occurrence from March to October, a reminder of the lush greenery that surrounds us. As our neighborhood was once a wooded area, there are numerous trees, providing ample shade, but also generating a sea of leaves each autumn, which requires us to rake and burn them every year. The smell of burning leaves is a welcome sign that fall has arrived, and lately, with the lack of a harsh winter, it feels like the season has been prolonged. Our garage, located at the back of the house, is where I often work on my truck or various projects, and when the garage doors are open, I feel more connected to the community. It's a quiet and peaceful atmosphere, especially on holidays like Thanksgiving and Christmas, when families gather and there's a noticeable increase in parked cars. Overall, I'm content with living here, and if it weren't for the through traffic, it would be a perfect place to call home.

For those who haven't experienced it firsthand, living in a high desert community can be hard to truly comprehend. You'd think that miles and miles of brown as far as the eye can see would be a given, but trust me, it's a distinct sensation. Whenever you catch a glimpse of a lush lawn, you immediately realize that its owner is making a significant investment in lawn care. When I first moved here in the 90s, homes were few and far between, giving the area a wide-open feel. Although new developments have sprouted up, the overall landscape hasn't changed all that much – it's starting to resemble a city, but that's a trend happening in many places. The people in my neighborhood are generally friendly, but, like any community, it's a mix of good and bad. I'm fortunate to be surrounded by friendly long-time residents, which makes this a relatively nice place to live. The local shops are mostly chains like Food 4 Less and Smart & Final, and if you're looking for upscale options, you're in for a drive. I rarely see any high-end stores like Whole Foods around here. Construction is the dominant industry in my area, which isn't surprising given the abundance of open spaces still waiting to be developed. That worries me a bit – I left a big city to escape the chaos, and I'm not eager to go back. My full-time job as a drywall and T-bar installer is, of course, in the construction field. What I appreciate about my home, though, is the unique wildlife. People come to the high desert for its stark beauty, and the challenging ecosystems that have formed here support a diverse range of wildlife. It's crucial for human residents to learn about and respect the non-human inhabitants of this environment, or risk disrupting the delicate balance. My family and I have adapted well to the local wildlife, and my kids are fascinated by lizards and desert creatures – as I write this, they're trying to catch different specimens outside. If you're interested in visiting, the area has some attractions worth checking out. Victorville is a great place for families to experience the desert, and if you can plan your visit to coincide with the annual San Bernardino County Fair, you'll get a taste of the local culture. The nearby Wrightwood offers a unique experience, especially if you're interested in winter sports, and the Victor Valley Museum showcases the region's natural history and cultural significance.

When asked to describe my neighborhood, I offer a unique perspective. While others who respond to this question are likely homeowners with their own individual lives, my situation is a bit of an anomaly. For me, my neighborhood is the college campus where I reside, and the people in my dormitory are my community. I also consider the surrounding campus as a neighborhood, albeit to a lesser extent. Despite this peculiarity, my neighborhood shares some commonalities with conventional ideas about neighborhoods. Like any typical neighborhood, mine has houses, people, stores, and parks. Let's start by examining the "houses" that make up my neighborhood. Before diving in, it's essential to note the different types of housing in my area. There are three main types: apartments, houses, and dormitory houses. 

First, the apartments typically have 2-4 people per room, with 4-6 rooms per floor. These buildings usually have two floors, accommodating around 20 people. Second, there are houses available for rent, primarily to individuals affiliated with the school. These often have 2-4 bedrooms, but there are only a few of these scattered throughout the neighborhood. Lastly, there are the dorm rooms, which house hundreds of students, usually with two people per room, with some exceptions. This type of housing is the most common in my neighborhood. 

Moving on to the people, my school prides itself on its diversity, and this is reflected in the neighborhood's demographics. There are individuals from various cultures and age groups living here. The professional staff typically reside in the houses, while newer students stay in dormitory-style housing, and older students live in apartments. The people in this neighborhood are too complex to be captured in a simple description, so let's move on to the stores and parks. Since my school is essentially a self-contained neighborhood, it has an array of stores and a single park. The stores offer a mix of dining options and the school's unique merchandise and grocery stores, making it possible to find everything within the neighborhood's boundaries. The park serves as a playground for the diverse community, kept clean and crime-free by its members.

After spending about 10 years in my current neighborhood, I've accumulated some insight into the community. I must admit that when I first moved here from Riverdale to Stockbridge, I was heartbroken. I missed my old home and the people I left behind, and my parents made the difficult decision to relocate for a better life. Over time, I adjusted to my new surroundings, made some friends, and encountered some acquaintances who turned out to be adversaries. Although I never took the time to get to know my neighbors thoroughly, there are a few individuals who have stood out as remarkable exceptions - Mr. Glen and his children, as well as Dennis, who lived right next door to me. They've become like family, and I'm grateful for their presence in my life. One fond memory that stands out is my family's attendance at Mr. Glen's wedding. It was a joyous occasion, and I'm looking forward to the day I can provide a similar celebration for my future wife. When Ms. Veda, Mr. Glen's wife, removed her leg strap, I caught it, but unfortunately, I missed catching the flowers. We danced the night away, and I had a wonderful time with Marsharii, one of their daughters. I've lost touch with her since, but I hope she's thriving. The neighborhood itself can be confusing, even with the aid of a GPS, but that's allowed me to explore its nooks and crannies. I've only explored a small portion of it so far, usually with my friends Kason and Curtis. We'd often spend hours playing video games and enjoying life to the fullest. I'd also visit the park to connect with nature, which brings me a sense of calmness and peace. I'd often bring sticks from Home Depot to practice my balance and, when I can, my bokken wooden sword. It's exhilarating to engage in activities I love. Although I haven't played tennis or basketball in a while, the courts are still a reminder of the good times I had with my dad and his friend Mr. Graves. They pushed me and my best friend to excel, and we had a blast. I'm reminded that there are many more happy memories waiting to be made in this neighborhood, and I'm excited to see what the future holds.

Living in my neighborhood, which is just a stone's throw away from the college I attend, has its advantages. I'm surrounded by a mix of old and new apartment buildings, with some restaurants and bars that offer a lively atmosphere without breaking the bank. One of these bars recently underwent a name change, and while it's a bit pricier than the others, the service and drinks are decent, and the people are friendly. The demographics of the area are fairly diverse, with a mix of college students and lower-income residents, given the relatively affordable housing options. There's also a lot of young families in the area, thanks to the nearby elementary school within walking distance of my apartment. I've had minimal interactions with my neighbors, and that's just fine by me - I've noticed that they tend to be a laid-back crowd, often frequenting the area for its relaxed vibe. The air freshener my landlord installed outside their door after complaints about the smell of weed was a bit of an amusing touch, although it can be seen as a bit condescending. 

The buildings around me have a mix of old facades and possibly renovated interiors. A short walk down the street leads to some newer apartments, but I'm not a fan of them. They appear to be hastily constructed and overpriced, and I think it's unfair that management gets away with charging such high rent despite the subpar construction. A nearby eatery serves food on paper plates and microwaves most of its dishes, while a gas station across the street has a reputation for being a difficult workplace. However, a recent city-funded renovation has improved the road, adding a wide sidewalk, lush greenery on the medians and along the roadsides, and a more aesthetically pleasing atmosphere. My apartment complex is surrounded by a dense canopy of trees, which is a welcome respite from the more barren landscapes found in other areas. Behind my building, there's a tree line and another set of apartments. Just a block away on 43rd street, the scenery takes a turn for the worse - the sidewalks are in disrepair, and the buildings look rundown. The presence of many trees on this street might be an attempt to mask the area's shortcomings. While there have been some incidents of crime in the area, particularly at a nearby apartment complex, I try not to hold it against the entire neighborhood. There are other apartments with a similar issue across the street from me, and it's hard to blame just one place. Despite its imperfections, I've grown to appreciate my current living situation. The proximity to the university is convenient, and there are multiple bus stops nearby, making it easy to get to the local store or downtown.

My neighborhood, a collection of duplexes arranged in a cul-de-sac, has a quaint charm that makes it resemble a village from a bygone era. The uniform exterior, with its cheerful yellow paint, white porches, and green metal roofs, belies the unique character of each home within. The residents, while not all close friends, share a sense of camaraderie that's hard to find in today's fast-paced world. You can often find us standing at the end of the driveway, chatting with one another while our children play and laugh together. It's a refreshing respite from the digital haze that surrounds us, and it's a scene that feels almost idyllic. Our neighborhood is surrounded by rolling fields, tall trees, and vast blue skies with clouds that seem to stretch on forever. However, this serene atmosphere can be disrupted by the harsh realities of nature, as we recently experienced during a tornado warning. The sound of sirens sent us scurrying for shelter, and I found myself huddled in my bathtub with my youngest dog and a few pillows, while my larger companion remained in the living room, uneasy and vocal. The only sound was the relentless hail pounding against the ground, and when it finally stopped, the road seemed to steam in the sudden temperature drop. The hail, which had been relentless just moments before, melted instantly on the hot pavement. As the storm cleared, a double rainbow appeared in the sky, and I quickly grabbed my camera to capture the breathtaking sight. The streets remained quiet for a while, but as the sun broke through the clouds, life returned to normal, and our neighborhood resumed its peaceful rhythm. It's a beautiful place to call home, especially for someone like me who recently moved from New Hampshire to North Carolina. I adore the warm accents and friendly demeanor of our neighbors, and I'm grateful for the sense of community that defines our little corner of the world. My apartment, like all the others, may look the same from the outside, but each one has its own unique character and charm. Some are cozy and intimate, while others are surprisingly spacious. I love strolling through the large field behind my home and making my way down to the pond, where I've spotted deer and been serenaded by the haunting melodies of the bullfrog. It's a magical place, just a short drive from the bustling city of Charlotte. Each morning, I'm greeted by the cheerful crowing of roosters from the nearby farms, and in the evenings, I'm treated to the gentle braying of a friendly donkey. I feel fortunate to have discovered this hidden gem of a neighborhood.

I remember my neighborhood vividly - it's where I first settled in during the summer before eighth grade. Making friends wasn't easy at first, but I eventually connected with two local boys, one living just two houses down and the other on our street. Though they're no longer around, the memories remain. Much like my neighborhood, the residents have remained largely the same over time. Our neighborhood is quintessentially suburban, with two-story houses and a distinctively peaceful atmosphere. Children's laughter echoes through the streets every weekend and warm-weather days, creating a sense of community. The neighborhood is relatively quiet, except for the occasional weekend bustle. I've never had any issues with my neighbors, who, it seems, respect each other's boundaries. I've had packages delivered multiple times without incident, a testament to the trust we share. A nearby park, just a minute or two from my doorstep, holds a special place in my heart. It's where I formed unforgettable memories playing basketball, football, and baseball with my friends. Though I also have a painful recollection from those days - a particularly gruesome nose-elbow incident - the good memories far outweigh the bad. Today, when I visit that park, it's often to spend time with my younger cousin's kids, watching them play and reminisce about my own carefree days. The park's nostalgic value has only grown stronger over time. Our neighborhood is a melting pot of cultures, with diverse dining options within a one-mile radius. From Chinese to Indian, Mexican to Italian, you can find a variety of cuisines to satisfy your cravings, although many residents have switched to food delivery services like GrubHub and DoorDash. The neighborhood is dotted with fast-food shops, but you can also find authentic eateries, including a few pizza joints. The local stores cater to all your needs, with dry cleaners, a Walgreens, a CVS, and a Jewel-Osco grocery store, not to mention an Indian-owned store for those craving homemade or store-bought Indian delights. I'm grateful for my neighborhood, especially when I see the horror stories of others on social media. It's heartwarming to know I'm part of a community where neighbors respect and support one another.

My town has a charming, laid-back quality that makes it easy to overlook, but don't let its unassuming nature fool you – Johnston has a significant impact on the agricultural world. Dubbed the Peach Capital of the World, the town proudly wears this title on its welcome sign. The landscape is dotted with rolling farmland, either devoted to peach trees or cattle grazing. Homes, often two stories tall with metal or gray roofs, are spaced generously apart, many set far back from the road to allow for expansive front fields that occasionally host animals or crops. In the heart of the town, a single stoplight stands at a four-way intersection, marking the spot where most of the local businesses are concentrated. Here, you'll find a handful of eateries – Hong Kong, a family-run Chinese restaurant, Fiesta Mexican Restaurant, and Gary's, a small burger chain – along with Maxwell and Halford Drug, a beloved, family-owned pharmacy famous for its Cherry Coca-Cola. Independent Grocers Alliance (IGA) is the town's only grocery store, though many residents prefer to shop at a larger store in Batesburg-Leesville for most of their groceries. Dollar General, on the other hand, is the most popular store, bustling with activity from opening to closing. Nearby, Possibilities Furniture & More offers a wide range of home furnishings, and its owner, a well-respected member of the community, even delivers items purchased in-house. Attached to the furniture store is Clark's Cuts and Kennels, a pet groomer that provides a variety of services. Medical and veterinary care is available in separate, yet small, practices located outside the main part of town. The town's sole elementary school, Johnston Elementary, educates students through fifth grade, after which they attend school in the neighboring town. Although there are no parks within the town, a new 2.5-acre recreational area is currently under development, aimed at providing families with additional leisure activities and luring potential residents to the area. It's a small town with limited entertainment options, featuring no movie theaters, bowling alleys, or a wide variety of restaurants. Nevertheless, its quiet charm makes it easy to miss, even when driving by in a flash.

The first time I discovered my neighborhood, I was listening to a podcast about individuals who had vanished. It was an unexpected revelation. Almost every apartment in the area was commanding over a thousand dollars a month, and I'd never heard a whisper about that story or any of my friends had. Perhaps it's the struggle that makes us overlook such things. We've all become accustomed to living on a shoestring budget, and we've learned to adapt. We find solace in the worn smell of second-hand toys and mothballed clothing, like the scent of a bygone era. Adulthood often strips us of our senses, but the flea market has a way of asserting itself, reminding us of simpler times. Our neighborhood is a treasure trove of thrift stores, with three within walking distance. If you start on one end, you can visit two charity thrift stores, a library, a rare bookstore, and a curio shop. It's a tranquil oasis in the midst of a bustling downtown area, where cars and people fill the streets every morning. Yet, inside these thrift stores, all is quiet, a haven from the chaos outside. As the city continues to develop, it's becoming more crowded, but the thrift stores remain a serene retreat. The city's growth is evident, with one of the largest e-commerce empires calling it home, but it still struggles to accommodate its rapid expansion. The vibe is reminiscent of New York – everyone is focused on their own goals, and personal space is respected. You can be alone, independent, and quiet, and people will leave you be. This is a stark contrast to the South, where being considerate is seen as caring. We can maintain our shells, and the city will continue to thrive, much like the waves on a beach. It's a lively place to be, with the pianist next door and the amateur vocalists upstairs creating a constant symphony. In a way, we've formed a community of friends, rather than just a collection of strangers. We come together for celebrations, support each other through difficult times, and help one another when needed. I feel fortunate to be a part of this community, as I genuinely enjoy my neighbors and they treat me with kindness. I make an effort to keep our living space tidy and return favors, and they reciprocate in kind. I appreciate the simple pleasures of receiving mail from them and being able to return the favor. It's a small but meaningful connection that makes me feel like I haven't completely lost my way in this massive, dehumanizing modernist sprawl.

The area I live in is a quintessential representation of the classic cookie-cutter suburbia. My neighborhood, in particular, is thoroughly under the spell of a homeowner's association, evident in the uniformity of the well-manicured single-family homes. Upon entering, you'll notice the perfectly maintained yards, complete with neatly landscaped grass, decorative pebbles, and short driveways. The occasional small tree adds a touch of variety, but the overall aesthetic is remarkably consistent. Every house boasts a two-car garage, and the roads are immaculately paved, free from even the slightest pothole. The architecture is a mix of single-story and two-story homes, though the majority lean towards the former. One of the most distinctive features of the neighborhood is the unique mail system, where a large cluster of mailboxes at the end of the street serves the entire community, accessible only by key. The package lockers are similarly centralized, a testament to the HOA's emphasis on uniformity. Located on the outskirts of the nearby city, my neighborhood straddles the line between rural and suburban living. The result is an abundance of open space, making it easy to enjoy activities like walking your dog or taking a stroll without ever leaving home. The community boasts multiple pools, all well-maintained and gated, as well as walking trails perfect for a leisurely evening stroll. The neighborhood is primarily inhabited by retirees, who have created a safe and tight-knit community where everyone looks out for one another. A smaller yet notable presence of middle-aged and young professionals adds a touch of diversity to the mix. The nearby city is surprisingly large, with a small-town feel that belies its substantial population. It offers a wide range of amenities, including a single, albeit modest mall, as well as an assortment of stores catering to various tastes and budgets. Whether you're in the market for organic groceries or bargain deals, you'll find it within a 15-minute drive. The best part? You can enjoy all these conveniences without sacrificing the peace and quiet of a suburban lifestyle.

I reside in a small Midwestern town that borders the suburbs of a major city, with my neighborhood on the east side being the most economically disadvantaged area within the town. Property values here are generally low, with most homes rented to or owned by low-income individuals. Yet, this doesn't mean my neighborhood is unappealing or unpleasant. The residents are friendly and welcoming, often exchanging warm smiles and greetings when I walk down the street. Although the crime rates are slightly higher than in other parts of town, they remain relatively low. There have been a few violent incidents in the past decade, including shootings and a homicide, within a few blocks of my home – a sobering reminder of the challenges faced by my community. Our next-door neighbors lost their son in a shooting outside a nearby bar last year, a tragedy that has left a lasting impact. Thankfully, my family hasn't been directly affected by crime, except for the occasional missing item from our porch when we forget to bring it inside. The town I call home has been grappling with the devastating effects of the opioid epidemic that has ravaged many parts of the United States. The loss of lives to fentanyl overdoses has been profound, but there are also encouraging signs of resilience. The town boasts several addiction rehabilitation centers and Narcan training sessions for families and friends of those struggling with addiction. Amidst these challenges, my town has many redeeming qualities. My son's elementary school has an exceptional staff, from the principal to the teachers and support staff, creating a welcoming environment where everyone feels valued. His special needs haven't led to any bullying, thanks to the school's positive atmosphere, and he adores attending. The PTO is actively engaged, organizing various events throughout the year to foster family involvement and educational progress. To ensure no child goes hungry, the school provides free breakfast and lunch to all students, making school fees, supplies, and field trips affordable for families struggling financially. Every child and family is treated with dignity and respect, regardless of their financial situation. The City Council and staff have made significant improvements to the town's appearance, including repaving roads, landscaping, and refurbishing city parks. However, most of these enhancements have focused on the town's central areas and the west side, where shopping districts and main roads are located. My neighborhood, on the other hand, has lagged behind, a source of frustration for local residents. Despite these imperfections, I still find myself enjoying life in this town. The people are friendly, the schools are excellent, there are sufficient shopping options to meet our needs, and our home, although not particularly valuable, is comfortable and suitable for our family. After 16 years of calling this town home, we can't imagine living anywhere else.

The diversity of my neighborhood is truly what makes it so vibrant.  Nestled on a hill, surrounded by structures rich in history, my community is a melting pot of cultures.  I reside in a 7-story apartment building directly across from the historic live theater, and just a short walk away is an eclectic arcade bar that draws in people of all kinds on warm summer evenings.  During the peak summer months of June and July, you'll often see a line of people waiting to enter this popular gathering spot.  A few blocks up lies the city's central park, which is surprisingly spacious considering its location in the heart of the community.  The park is enclosed by concrete walls, with stairs integrated into the design.  In the harsh winter months, the homeless population sets up their temporary shelters in a tidy row along the sidewalk and stairs, providing them with some much-needed warmth and a sense of community.  The fact that they're placed in a centralized area, rather than on the outskirts of town, helps them stay relatively warm during the rare snowfall and frequent downpours.  Additionally, their proximity to the local family center, where they can access essential services like showers and laundry facilities, is a vital lifeline.

However, what I cherish most about my neighborhood is the people themselves.  Despite its notorious past, Hilltop, where I reside, has undergone a remarkable transformation.  This once-notorious neighborhood was once plagued by gang violence, earning it a notorious reputation on the West Coast.  Even decades later, stories of the federal government's efforts to clean up the streets still circulate, passed down through generations.  The residents, though still facing challenges, have worked tirelessly to maintain a sense of community and cleanliness.  They take pride in their city and their neighborhood, and it shows in the way they come together to address issues and look out for one another.  The phrase "don't walk around the Hill after dark" is often repeated to newcomers, a lingering warning from the past, but to me, it's a reminder of the societal conditioning that still permeates our society.  Perhaps it's because I've learned to navigate these nuances or perhaps the community has accepted me as one of their own, but I feel a deep connection to the people and the culture of this neighborhood.  I've experienced firsthand the kindness and generosity of the residents, who have offered me a jacket or a helping hand when I needed it most.  It's a place where strangers become friends, where community is more than just a word – it's a way of life.  No matter where life takes me, Hilltop will always be home.  There's something about walking the streets at night, feeling the energy of the community, that makes me feel alive.  It's a place where people look beyond the surface level and see the person behind, where I've been offered a sense of belonging and acceptance.  This is what makes Hilltop so special – a place where everyone is valued and seen.

I reside in rural Michigan, specifically in a small town surrounded by the serenity of nature.  Our area seamlessly blends farmland with quaint tourist cities, devoid of the hustle and bustle of big city malls, chain stores like Wal-mart and Target, and even trendy restaurants like Applebee's.  Everything is within a driving distance, which I've come to appreciate in this picturesque corner of the world.  My hometown boasts a unique charm, with the majestic Lake Michigan lapping against one side and the tranquil Lake Charlevoix on the other.  Every direction I look, I can spot a beach where I can dip my toes in the water.  The neighborhood reflects the essence of small-town America, with homes that are far from cookie-cutter structures.  Our houses are a mix of old and new, some with basements that are easily visible from the road.  Aluminum siding, vibrant colors, and lush lawns are just a few characteristics that make our neighborhood distinctive.  It's a place where families thrive, where hardworking individuals strive to make a living, and where neighbors know neighbors, and community spirit runs deep.  On any given day, you can see kids playing in the streets, people walking their dogs, biking, or rollerblading.  Our community is a place where time stands still, where neighbors wave at each other, and where everyone seems to know their place.  The lawns are well-manicured, with neatly trimmed bushes and plants, giving our neighborhood a sense of warmth and welcoming charm.  While it may not be a neighborhood that instantly impresses with its grandeur, it's a place that feels like home, where families can grow and thrive in a safe and peaceful environment.  Just a short walk away lies the county sheriff's department, health department, and recycling center, all of which serve our community with ease.  We have baseball and softball fields nearby, where you can hear the excitement of the game, and the airport is just a stone's throw away, with the sound of small planes taking off and landing.  You can walk to the local ice cream shop, or ride your bike to the park, which is just a few blocks away.  It's a wonderful place to call home.

original_texts:
Since I live in a large city, my neighborhood is extremely diverse. Residential areas are dispersed, seemingly randomly, between commercial areas, where a variety of businesses are run. Some of these businesses are made up of offices, while others are various stores, restaurants, and places of entertainment. There is no shortage of new restaurants to eat at, or stores to shop in. While some stores are large, well-known, brands that are owned by large corporations, small boutiques are also increasingly popular. They are not only located in various malls, but they also line the streets, which are often in walking distance of neighborhoods that would otherwise be quiet and serene, if not surrounded by so many points of interest. There are also a couple of nearby parks, and I have noticed that people frequent these parks with their young children. Speaking of the people, thereâ€™s actually quite a bit of diversity within my neighborhood. In one small location, we have a prominent LGBTQ+ community, an Orthodox Jewish community, and a collection of refugees and immigrants from the former Soviet Union. Spanning a little further outside of my neighborhood, there are many more individuals of various races and origins, although they are sometimes broken up into their own little communities within the city. We have locations known as Korea town, China town, Little Armenia, and many more, which are only a few miles away. However, only a few miles can prove to be a very lengthy drive. Driving a distance of only 10 miles can sometimes span two hours, due to traffic, especially during rush hour. Hardly anyone in my city walks anywhere, though. While certain locations of interest are inevitably close-by, the city is huge, and people do not generally prefer to commute on foot. As a result, we also have some of the worst traffic in the world, and it can be difficult to find parking spots just about anywhere. Ironically enough, there has been a great deal of construction in recent years, as large apartment buildings are being added to the city. It is seems to be a popular destination, but many residents are disappointed by the prospect of even more people moving in, and even more vehicles on the roads. There are many different types of houses in my city, however. Not everyone lives, or wishes to live, in a large apartment building. Residential areas are made up of houses, of various sizes, and smaller apartment buildings and condominiums. Some properties contain single-family homes, while others contain duplexes. This is true even within my immediately neighborhood, so there is also no lack of diversity in regards to housing options. Similarly, the neighborhood is made up of people of varying ages, and to be perfectly honest, I am not familiar with the majority of my neighbors. It is not really a tight-knit community these days, although I have many memories from my childhood of playing outside with my next-door neighbor, and a few other friends from the neighborhood, who were all close to my age.
My neighborhood is interesting. Most of the houses are single family, but there are a few homes that have been split into two, while still being attached, if that makes much sense. My home has a small yard in front of it and a small driveway to the left of the house. It, like most of the others, reminds you of a time not so long ago where living in the suburbs was the American dream. This dream at once seemed to embrace the people of this country, but now its pulling away. But my neighborhood and many more still remain, still call out to us and those who visit that the dream is still alive, and we are still holding onto it as best we can. The people don't feel as optomistic as they used to, the upkeep of the little yards are not what they used to be, but there is still a car or two in every driveway, still the youth play as if the world around them was the whole of their existence. The public school that has been here for almost 90 years still stands, still seems conjure a future in today's youth, while stirring up nostalgia in the older residents. The churches are few and far between, mostly empty, but the basketball courts are still full. All of the homes look different, but feel the same. There is a large supermarket called super "A" that has been owned by a large Yemni family, who are quite possible the only Arab family in the neighborhood. The vast majority of the residents are African American. The streets are wide and the kids usually play footbal, only stopping to allow the cars to pass. Most of the people in my neighborhood have been here for generations and most can tell stories of a past where everyone knew everyone. There was a karate school, but when hollywood stopped making karate kid movies, the kids stopped wanting to be the karate kid, so its now a pharmacy, because drugs make everything better, or so I've heard. There is also a small movie theatre that plays old movies at a discounted price, spared from the crowds by the youth's disdane for its lack of just release titles, but favored by the elders, who think it is a small price to pay for a night out, without the kids of course. There is a single expressway that passes through my town. Though the exit and entrance are in the town next to ours. There was once a petition to get and exit for our town. The youth supported it, while the elders refused. It seems that having the expressway in our town would ruin it, so said the elders who eventually persuaded the city council to deny the request. They are building a new highschool, and we are trying to decide on a mascott for our town. I think a cyborg with a country accent and a log cabin would be then best representation of my town.
You might pass it up on first glance - after all, it is a residential area behind a shopping strip, not a place one would assume there are places to live. At least, not places most people would want to live. But if you go behind the old, abandoned Whole Foods and walk back behind the hotels which are only occupied annually aside from a few stints in the summertime for family reunions, you'll find an entire bustling community. Within these communities, on these streets, are a handful of apartment complex - situated next to each other carefully like Russian nesting dolls that have been scrupulously, carefully taken apart and set beside each other in a line down the road, piecemeal. The first apartments you come upon are ones which have been on the news for some fairly unsavory dealings, so we won't focus on those too much - appearances, after all, can be deceiving. But the apartments beside that complex, and the two complexes beside that one, are a whole other world that almost no one living in this area knows about. Across from those complexes is a community college's satellite campus - a quiet, sleepy set of buildings standing sentinel beside the road, where students putter in with coffee in hand, yawning at 7 in the morning to begin their sleepy days. The iron gates creak open to admit them one by one, while commuters shake their fists out the window and groan at them for holding up traffic on days attendance is higher. The road t-bones into another residential road, with a park on one side and a rehabilitation center for people who have broken bones in unfortunate circumstances. The treatment center boasts cheerful porch furniture, and a lazily undulating ceiling fan which churns the warm, thick summertime air back and forth. Children run back and forth in the grass at the park across the street, cartwheeling and pinwheeling across the prickly green stalks while bees lazily turn in the flower patches by the road. Old retired folks walk their dogs on the walking path, scowling at the teenagers on their skateboards and nodding demurely at the teenage girls clustered by the playground equipment, gossiping about boys and the latest YouTube sensations. There is a sushi place in a strip mall beside the park that has inexpensive food but never seems too busy - a swimming supply store right beside that, and a nail salon nestled in between. You could fill your pool for the season while getting a manicure and eating hibachi chicken, all at once - the beauty of a strip mall. There is a frozen yogurt place there too, one of the DIY kind, and you often see the teens in the park clutching cold, sweating cups of frozen yogurt covered in toppings while they do stunts on their skateboards and vape because they believe it to be the coolest. The neighborhood in question is a slice of Americana - a piece of history in the sleepy south where hardly anything changes, not even time.
“Where is everything?” she asked as we drove past the corn fields which filled the horizon. “This is it!” I said, knowing she’d be in shock of the sparseness of the open landscape. She was from a town in which the grocery store was a 5 minute walk from her house--she’d never seen this much open space in her life. Taken back by the ubiquity of corn fields, I shared with her what it was like to grow up in rural Ohio, and in that moment, she finally knew who I was and where I came from. Driving down a two-lane country road, you will reach a quarry which is filled with water. Just past it is the small development I live in. The houses are mostly composed of brick and stucco. All the houses have at least a half an acre of land to themselves which everyone takes pride in maintaining. During springtime, annually planted flowers are abundant along with the midwestern trees that change with every season. The driveways are all filled with the highest end Mercedes Benz luxury cars that glisten in the midday sun after a good, old-fashioned car wash. Continuing along the road toward my grey stucco home, my Korean neighbor is always outside with a friendly face. He tends to spend the entire day mowing his lawn and can be heard singing over his mower’s hum. Everyone in the neighborhood gets a laugh out of him, but he is always genuine and an amazing person with a unique history. He has grown older and has lost some of his wit as he aged. In his past he was a doctor and usually blends in with the grass and his John Deer Zero Turn mower. Finally, you will reach my home. In the side yard, geese are abundant and are chased by our Terrier. Out back, there is a small stream that feeds into the quarry. Here, you can hear bullfrogs, the stream, and the occasional “moo” from the nearby farms. Across the handmade wooden bridge is an untouched oasis filled with naturally growing trees, herbs, and wildflowers. Here was where I spent most of my childhood. From building tree forts to ‘hunting’ animals (which mostly consisted of chasing them), there was always something to do and usually a neighborhood child available for friendship. The winters in my small town can be painfully brutal, yet there is nothing more beautiful. The yard transforms from a sea of green into an empty wilderness. The trees that once housed vibrant pink, purple, and orange flowers turn into barren skeletons of bark. When blessed with the occasional snowfall, a winter wonderland appears overnight. The backyard is lined with snow angels made by my little sister, and snowmen. My sister and I fought frequently as kids, and during the winter, snowballs were our weapon of choice. We’d build massive igloo-like forts to house our weapons, usually with branches, like an arsenal. In our own little wonderland was where we played pretend during a time where nothing else mattered. We were just young kids without a care in the world.
The first thing you have to understand about Portland, Oregon is the definition of "weird". The unofficial town slogan, on the back of a building that serves as a pizza joint, bar, music venue, strip club, and skirts the law on at least half of these endeavors, is "Keep Portland Weird". To some, this is a small cry to remember the Portland of the 90's and early 2000's, a Portland that was less known and less expensive, generating creative and unique subcultures. To others, it is a beckoning call - come to Portland, where people will still call you weird, but as a compliment this time. Despite the influx of affluent Californians and the constant construction of condominiums to house these Californians, Portland is still weird. Weird does not mean always accepting, but it does mean accepting of things that are normally not accepted. Weird does not mean we do not have modern conveniences and modern fights. Like the rest of the country, we buy most of our things from China. There are a million ways of being weird, of being not normal, but Portland has plenty of normal. Portland has yoga and hipsters and business professionals. Perhaps weird means we just take all of this less seriously. In my neighborhood, as in many Portland neighborhoods, we have colorful houses, home gardens with flowers and herbs and vegetables lining the streets, and free boxes in the summertime. Free boxes are traditionally cardboard boxes containing items someone is getting rid of, but they can be plastic bags or boxes. They contain something magical, a treasure just perfect for the person wandering by, a surprising amount of the time. Free boxes tend to have clothes and books, but they can have anything. The magical potential of walking through a Southeast Portland neighborhood is what Portland is all about. That is, what Portland is all about to me, but I am just one variety of weird among thousands. Some people I live among would never dream of picking their clothes out of a box on the sidewalk. Those people go to goat yoga (yes, yoga with real live goats) or Timbers matches (the city's soccer team). Portland is full of people who love all sorts of things. Portland is full of people who pursue our dreams, or dream about pursuing our dreams while spending too much time at the bar. Yes, Portland has a drug problem. Drug problems tend to be (at their root) mental health problems, and the constant rain through much of the year, plus the dreary clouds, appear to be a contributor. Portland has a homelessness problem too, which no one seems to know what to do with. The homeless population is drawn by the social services Portland offers, better than in most parts of the country, but our services are insufficient, as in all parts of the country. The non-homeless population wavers between care and hatred. In this, we are not weird at all.
The mountains are always there. In the north, bearing witness to the sun’s journey every dawn and every dusk. No matter how much I forget about them or how caught up with work and life I am to notice, they are there, unwavering, unopposed, and unphased by life’s tribulations. Then on days when I am the most stressed and wound, they demand to be seen, and when I turn to them they let me rest my anxious soul, lending me some strength to go on, one day at a time. I first moved here when I started my undergrad, and the mountains to the north of campus where what first captivated me. Sure, the university has its own share of breathtaking sights in buildings and ponds and trees, which have their own share of my heart, but it’s the mountains that really holds its throne. The rest of the town is beautiful in its own right. There are countless cafés that were home to many hours of caffeine fueled cramming. One can walk or take the bus just a little further to the downtown area and be enveloped in an aura of antiquity by the faded colored bricks that line restaurants and office buildings. It is here that this seemingly suburban town shows as much bustle and vigor as it’s neighboring urban city. This doesn’t last for many blocks though, as one can escape, once again, to the serene small town by passing the library. This dichotomy of atmospheres in such proximity truly give this city a wonderous vibe as if it was beckoning to be explored. With this, it is easy to create many a cherished memory, each in association with a certain part of town. Whether it is walking past the rusted swings in the park with friends after an all-nighter or running through the busy downtown to catch the movie in the fancy theater for which the university provided tickets. Alas, it is also home to many harsh memories, as all places are bound to be in life. The ponds, in particular, can be a rather fitting place for reflection as well as crying sessions at two in the morning in the middle of an existential crisis. The latter of which, I have more experience in. While watching the turtles and ducks and insects live out their lives, each with some contribution or role, I couldn’t help but wonder about my own sense of purpose as I struggled to navigate this mystery called life. So, I walked past the pond, and past the park and little houses that scream of suburbia, until I reached a main street. It was then that sun shined its brilliant rays atop the palm trees, painting the sky along the way, and as I looked up at the sunrise, I realized I was walking north. Sure enough, they were there, as they had always been. The sturdy overbearing mountains grazed the hazy blue and yellow sky more than any building in the horizon, and as if speaking without words, stirred in me my sense of perseverance.
If you are planning on visiting Bensonhurt, Brooklyn, you will not have a difficult time finding it! Public transportation is very accessible and is one of the most popular forms of transportation in New York City. Bensonhurt is a fairly urban neighborhood, so you will still feel as if you are in New York City. During your visit, be prepared to see the various Asian stores all around. Over the past two decades, Bensonhurt has received an influx of Asian inhabitants. Because of this, you will see an Asian-owned store at least every block as you are walking. Most popular are supermarkets and laundromats. Coincidentally, these businesses are very popular among local residents, as quality of food in the supermarkets are superb, the prices are much cheaper, and finally yet importantly, it is very convenient. Just nearby where I am, there are four Asian supermarkets within two minutes of walking distance from each other. This just adds to the convenience of accessing grocery. I’m not saying Bensonhurst is purely populated by Asian inhabitants, though. It is quite diverse all around, with immigrants and their first-generation and second-generation American children here. Most of the large and popular businesses in the local area are Asian owned. In addition to these Asian owned businesses, there is also a recently renovated park nearby, which has around ten basketball courts, a large field for soccer or baseball, four handball courts, swings, a playground for kids, and even a water fountain for kids to enjoy water in the summer. Since we are in New York City, of course the parks are very diverse. You will see all sorts of diversity here, able to play and get along well. In this neighborhood, there aren’t many large corporate buildings. The only buildings you’d find are ones for co-op living, or condominium apartments. The majority of living spaces here are two-family houses though. Most of the people are quite nice, however, very noisy. Every day, you’d hear cars blasting their music as they drive by your house, or constantly flooring the gas on their cars which will wake you up in the morning. If you are planning on visiting during night time, you should be on your guard. This neighborhood is fairly safe, but people are unpredictable. You may run into people who want to start trouble for no reason, bullies and thieves. I myself have been bullied in this neighborhood in the past via physical assault, but this was many years ago. Another recent incident involved package stealing. Although a common thing, there are package thieves in this neighborhood. Last but not least, although New York City has a fine for people not cleaning up after their dogs, people don’t follow the rules here. Every morning, you will see at least one dog waste on your way to the train station, or on your way to the supermarket. My biggest pet peeve is dog waste on the floor everywhere I go in this neighborhood. Be careful and keep your shoes clean!
There aren't many sidewalks where I live. Everything seems to flow downward, and my house sits right at the crest of the steepest hill in the neighborhood. People call it the "work out hill" because so many joggers like to run up it during their daily work out. As there aren't any sidewalks at all on my street everyone walks on the road. There road is pitted in a few places and can feel a bit hazardous to drive on. Some of the telephone and electric wires strung up around the block at tattered looking. It rains and storms a lot in our area, so branches and other debris often strike down the power lines and the constant repairs make them look checkered and patchwork-y. There's many tall evergreen trees all around everywhere you look. But people here hate the trees. They strive to cut down as many as possible because the trees obstruct the view of the ocean. That's why many of the houses are built so high up on the hill, with huge glass-fronted second stories that loom up one after the other to take in the view of the bay. It's gorgeous around sunset when the water seems to get lit up from below and the sky turns orange. It's cloudy more often than not, though, so you end up seeing most of the sunlight through a haze. Most days are overcast and damp. Moss grows on everything it can: roofs, cars, and railings. I once left my car parked out in my driveway for a month and when I went out to use it, it had turned green and furry with moss. Took me three hours to scrap it all off.
